However, this provision does not apply to an act performed by a person with qualified legal capacity as a legal representative of another person with qualified legal capacity.

t1:
Article 663
(1) If the parties have not specified the timing of the return of the bailed thing, the bailee may return the same at any time.
(2) If the timing of the return is specified, the bailee may not return the deposited thing prior to the due date unless there is a compelling reason to do so.
t2: If the parties have not specified the timing of the return of the Thing deposited, the depositary who has undertaken a deposit gratuitously may return the same and terminate the contract at any time.
ChatGPT_output: False. According to Article 663(1) of the Japanese Civil Code, if the parties have not specified the timing of the return of the bailed thing, the bailee may return the same at any time. However, this provision relates to "bailment" rather than "deposit". In bailment, a bailee takes temporary possession of the bailed property for a specific purpose and must return it to the bailor after the purpose is fulfilled. In contrast, in deposit, the depositary takes possession of the deposited thing for safekeeping, and must return it to the depositor upon demand. If the timing of the return is not specified, the depositary is generally required to return the deposited thing "within a reasonable time" after receiving a demand for its return from the depositor (Article 633 of the Civil Code). There is no provision in the Civil Code that allows a depositary to unilaterally terminate a deposit agreement.
